settings.blog-title: LIFE AFTER LOCKDOWN: HOW TO FIND A ROUTINE THAT WORKS FOR YOU

settings.text: As the world begins to slowly re-open and life resumes some semblance of normality, reactions will be mixed. Some are raring to go, others are a little reserved. However you feel, returning to a routine that has already been flipped on its head isn’t easy; here are our tips on how to adjust.

settings.grid-content:
1. Take things slowly

Not everyone is prepared to switch their life back to “normal” again. While some have been craving freedom for months, others are anxious to be around so many people after spending the past year in a bubble. Remember that we are all different and to take things at your own pace. Be gentle with yourself.

Small steps and adjustments will make easing back into normal life seem a lot less overwhelming. This could be meeting a friend outside for a coffee or picking up your takeout from a local restaurant rather than choosing home delivery. Next, you could try browsing a local boutique rather than risking a crowded high street.

You may find your confidence slowly returns as you become more ready to fully re-enter post-pandemic life. But also, don’t be hard on yourself if that’s not the case.

2. Acknowledge how you feel

It’s no secret that anxiety rates soared in the midst of the pandemic, and many of us are likely feeling the lingering effects of that stressful time. Rather than ignore these feelings and re-enter the world because you feel like you “have” to, really acknowledge and examine how you are feeling to discover what may be causing it.

It’s perfectly ok to decline invitations or reschedule if you suddenly find things too overwhelming; deal with your feelings in the moment and try again tomorrow. This is new to all of us.

3. Look after your mental health

Take things one day at a time; forget what the months ahead may hold and focus on today and tomorrow. The pandemic has taught us that there are a great deal of things that we cannot control, but what we can control is what we let impact our mental health. Whether that’s tuning out news or limiting your worries about the future, focus instead on positive coping strategies such as being in nature, exercise and meditation. Curate an environment where your mental health thrives, rather than suffers.

settings.text: As addictive as scrolling can be, we all know that social media often presents a false narrative. It’s easy to suffer from FOMO - the fear of missing out - when browsing through Instagram. Remember that what you’re seeing is a highlight reel, and it doesn’t have to be a reflection on your life. If a person’s constant posting of wild parties and shopping trips are making you feel bad, don’t hesitate to unfollow. If your social anxiety has reached levels of intensity that cause you to avoid socialising or if you struggle to leave the house, it may be time to seek professional help.

settings.grid-content:
4. Don’t forget your physical health

Whether you indulged in a daily lockdown walk or cultivated a thriving yoga practice in lockdown, many of us focused on fitness as a way of coping. But as elements of normality begin to resume, sticking to an exercise routine can not only be difficult, but also tiresome, especially with work and school runs to contend with.

Rather than reprimand yourself for skipped workouts, find ways to make exercise more enjoyable. If you don’t like running, then don’t do it. If spinning, yoga or crossfit has your heart, focus your efforts there. Enjoying your movement will make you more likely to continue, and exercise is the perfect way to release pent-up energy and help with lingering anxiety.

5. Continue your lockdown hobbies

When the world slowed down and life took place in the same four walls, many of us were left with ample amounts of time. Usually filled with socialising, shopping and exploring new places, new habits were born; we indulged in more baking, yoga, crafts, and gardening. If you’ve found yourself continuing these new hobbies as the world opens back up, do your best to stick with them. Having hobbies can do wonders for your mental health and gives you personal projects to focus on outside work and the kids.

If anxiety starts to spike or if worries set in, return to these hobbies to give you a safe space, and let them help you, even if all you do is bake banana bread once a week.

6. Reach for your comforts

Take solace in what you enjoy, especially if you’ve had a day of pushing yourself out of your comfort zone. If your morning yoga flow prepares you for the day ahead, make it a staple of your routine. If you’ve fully embraced lockdown fashion and prefer working from home in track pants and a soft cashmere jumper, don’t feel pressured to embrace the pantsuit once again.
